title: About
text:
I‚Äôm Guillaume Gilles, a former Banque de France financial analyst who now channels a decade of risk assessment and teaching into cybersecurity.

For over ten years at the Banque de France, I decoded macroeconomic patterns, assessed corporate resilience, and produced strategic insight for decision-makers. My academic side ran parallel ‚Äî teaching statistics, financial analysis, and information systems at top business schools, instilling analytical rigor and adaptability.
Hands-on with GitHub, I write, experiment, and explore: bridging data, defense, and human behavior to uncover and harden vulnerabilities.
Today, I‚Äôm immersed in cybersecurity, building skills in digital forensics, secure network design, and incident investigation. My passion lies at the nexus of data, security safeguards, and the behaviors that drive human error.


Python ¬∑ R ¬∑ Git ¬∑ Data analysis ¬∑ Risk awareness

title: GitHub Codespaces ‚ô•Ô∏è Quarto
text:
GitHub Codespaces are a development environment that‚Äôs hosted in the cloud. Codespace uses a container to provide common languages, tools, and utilities for development. Projects are customizable by configuring dev container files inside the repository (often known as configuration-as-code), which creates a repeatable codespace configuration. Once, initially configured, it is very simple to share custom-made development environment.
Each codespace is hosted by GitHub in a Docker container, running on a virtual machine. All GitHub personal accounts include: - \(120\) hours of free compute time. - \(15\) GB storage a month.


When you work in a codespace, the environment you are working in is created using a development container, or dev container, hosted on a virtual machine. You can configure the dev container for a repository so that codespaces created for that repository give you a tailored development environment, complete with all the tools and runtimes you need to work on a specific project.
The configuration files for a dev container are contained in a .devcontainer directory in your repository.



The primary file in a dev container configuration is the devcontainer.json file, usually located in the .devcontainer directory of your repository. It determine the environment of codespaces created for your repository.
{
  "image": "mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/universal:linux",
  "features": {}
}


The default Linux image is perfect start. It is based on Ubuntu packed with several programming language : Python, Node.js, JavaScript, TypeScript, C++, Java, C#, F#, .NET Core, PHP, Go, Ruby, and Conda.



Dev Container Features are self-contained units of installation code and development container configuration. Features are designed to install atop a wide-range of base container images.




"hostRequirements": While devcontainer.json does not focus on hardware or VM provisioning, it can be useful to know one container‚Äôs minimum RAM, CPU, and storage requirements.
"postCreateCommand": This command finalizes container setup when a dev container is created. We‚Äôll use it to install Python packges listed inside requirements.txt file.
"customization": Customize the user experience while working inside hte container.

title: Resume
text:
Conduct macroeconomic analyses and forecasts for the Nouvelle-Aquitaine region, covering topics such as inflation, growth, and economic trends. Prepare monthly synthesis reports on regional economic trends to support strategic decision-making for business leaders.






Teach descriptive and inferential statistics, as well as information systems management, to students in the Grande √âcole program. Apply adaptive teaching methods to accommodate varying student levels and foster academic success.






Deliver advanced financial analysis courses to master‚Äôs students, emphasizing real-world case studies to strengthen understanding of key concepts and their professional applications.






Analyzed the solvency of major French corporations, specializing in consolidated accounts (IAS/IFRS and French standards). Produced detailed financial reports to formalize credit risk recommendations, aiding strategic decisions for banking institutions.






Final-year internship focused on invoice control and accounting. Managed client invoicing and payment tracking, and contributed to monthly and annual closings.
